metadata.case_name: Zila Parishad, Kheri v. Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd.
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 1893 and 1894 of 1968; Civil Appeal No. 172 of 1969

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. is a company manufacturing sugar with factory situate in Gola Gokaran Nath in District Kheri, U.P.
Company purchases sugarcane in the District of Kheri, maintains some staff and makes certain advances to cultivators within the rural area of the said district.
Company's factory for manufacturing sugar was situate outside the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad (rural area).

Company assessed to circumstances and property tax under s.114 of District Boards Act, 1922 (repealed by U.P. Kshettra Samitis and Zila Parishads Adhiniyam, 1961, with similar s.121) for years 1961-1962 and 1962-63.
Company objected to levy but assessing authorities made the assessment.
Company appealed to Commissioner, Lucknow Division, who held tax wrongly imposed.
Zila Parishad, Kheri filed petition under Art. 226 challenging Commissioner's order; learned single Judge dismissed it.
Zila Parishad took matter by special appeal to Division Bench of Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, which appeal failed (judgment dated August 7, 1967 in Special Appeals Nos. 60 and 61 of 1966).
Business of company consisted of manufacturing sugar; essential to purchase raw material (sugarcane) at mill gate and in mofussil area including rural area in Kheri.
Company's activity in rural area consisted of regularly buying or purchasing sugarcane for business of manufacturing sugar in factory outside rural area.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the admitted facts any tax could be levied under s.121 of the Adhiniyam on the company whose factory was situate outside the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad, specifically whether the company was carrying on business in the rural area by purchasing sugarcane there.

petitioner_arguments.text: Company was purchasing sugarcane in rural area within jurisdiction for manufacturing sugar in its factory; purchases made within rural area means carrying on business in that area, liable to tax.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.121(a) U.P. Kshettra Samitis and Zila Parishads Adhiniyam, 1961

petitioner_arguments.text: Continuous and regular activity of buying sugarcane for period of at least six months constituted carrying on business in rural areas.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.121(a); Chas J. Webb Sons Co. v. CIT East Punjab (18 ITR 33)

respondent_arguments.text: Merely purchasing sugarcane essential for manufacturing sugar does not mean business carried on in places of purchase; analogous to purchasing machinery, spare parts, fuel wood from different places.
From businessman's standpoint, manufacturing sugar not carried on in districts from where raw material acquired.

court_reasoning.text: In same business, purchase of raw material like sugarcane essential but does not mean business carried on at purchase places; no separate profits from purchase.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Merely because purchase essential, does not mean business carried on there.

court_reasoning.text: Cases under Income-tax Act, 1922 (e.g. Webb Sons on s.42(3)) distinguishable as different provision deeming income from business connection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'operation' in IT Act covers purchase, but not relevant for 'carrying on business' in s.121(a).

court_reasoning.text: Observations in CIT Bombay v. Ahmedebhai Umarbhai not helpful as no separate profit from sugarcane purchase.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Buying raw material continuous but no separate income/profit.

court_reasoning.text: Zila Parishad Muzaffarnagar v. Jugal Kishore distinguished: there sugarcane crushed into Rab (saleable commodity) in rural area, unlike mere purchase here.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No process creating saleable commodity or finished product here.

holdings.text: Mere purchase of sugarcane (raw material) in rural area does not constitute carrying on business there under s.121(a) when manufacturing occurs outside.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chas J. Webb Sons Co. Inc. Philadelphia v. Commissioner of Income tax, East Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchase of raw material held operation under s.42(3) IT Act 1922, but not applicable to 'carrying on business' in s.121(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income tax, Bombay v. Ahmedebhai Umarbhai Co., Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations on activities as part of business if separate profit; no separate profit from sugarcane purchase.

precedents_cited.case_name: Zila Parishad, Muzaffarnagar v. Jugal Kishore Ram Swarup
precedents_cited.relevance: Firm crushed sugarcane into Rab (saleable) in rural area, carrying on business; unlike mere purchase here.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Kshettra Samitis and Zila Parishads Adhiniyam, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to impose tax on circumstances and property subject to conditions including carrying on business for 6 months in rural area.

statutes_cited.name: District Boards Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed; relevant provision for circumstances and property tax, similar to s.121.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems income from business connection/operations in British India; distinguished.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Zila Parishad's writ petition challenging Commissioner's order.

outcome.summary: The common point decided against levy of tax; mere purchase of sugarcane in rural area does not constitute carrying on business under s.121(a) where factory outside jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: Merely because the purchase of sugarcane was essential for the carrying on of business of manufacturing sugar it did not mean that any business was being carried on in the places where the sugarcane was being purchased.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: All that has to be decided... is whether the company was carrying on business in the rural area... when the activity attributed to it consisted of regularly buying or purchasing sugarcane for the business of manufacturing sugar in its factory which was outside the rural area.
key_quotes.speaker: court
